paragraphs.text: Enjoyed the analysis! Another reason Fandango may not be reliable is that they are in the business of trying to get people to purchase movie tickets. A movie with a higher rating means you are more likely to want to see it in theaters and therefore purchase movie tickets.
paragraphs.name: 9a59

4a1609d7c6d.title: I guess you could reconstruct my assumption(s) in terms of DGP, but I think it’s more clear to do…

paragraphs.text: I guess you could reconstruct my assumption(s) in terms of DGP, but I think it’s more clear to do the following reconstruction, with two assumptions:
paragraphs.name: 4e2a

paragraphs.text: Movie ratings express movie quality.
paragraphs.name: a25a

paragraphs.text: Most people think/experience most movies as being of an average quality.
Very useful (and very cool)! Am always in awe of folks with a “statistical” POV… and well-presented, thx!! ;-D
paragraphs.name: 106a

paragraphs.text: BTW, while Tomatoes often seems a bit skewed towards the extremes, I also appreciate the range of professional and amateur reviews they include, with two or three reviews usually providing a pretty good sense of the film overall, that sorta marches my own ‘criteria’.
paragraphs.name: 4d13

2d0ce6b5e5cd.title: How about trust none of them and just watch a movie.

paragraphs.text: How about trust none of them and just watch a movie. Given that there are as many opinions about a movie as there as people watching them, what one person/site says shouldn’t change your opinion. “Cult Classics” generally get bad reviews, people still enjoy them. Game of Thrones catches a lot of criticism for not being true to the books despite even…

82030a1cf160.title: The accuracy of ratings depends on the underlying data generating process (DGP).

paragraphs.text: The accuracy of ratings depends on the underlying data generating process (DGP). The author basically made an assumption: the DGP of movie ratings is normally distributed. And based on such an assumption, if a website’s movie rating is closest to normal distribution, then it has the best rating.
paragraphs.name: b28d

paragraphs.text: Amazing job!

I have to say that a lot of times I haven’t found scores useful at all. Reviews are useful for the extremes: when the majority of people say it is good, it tends to be good (8–10 scores), and also when they say it is very bad (1–4, normally people are not that cruel) they are bad. (I changed a little bit your…

d9146cdcc0c2.title: The IMDb’s “average of 7” has been a constant since its conception, but that does not mean you…

paragraphs.text:
The IMDb’s “average of 7” has been a constant since its conception, but that does not mean you cannot use it. I simply translate the score to my own scale:
≤4: not even a movie
4–6: bad
6–7: okeish
7–7.5: interesting
7.5–8: good
8–9: really good
≥9: masterpiece
paragraphs.name: 33c8

f459f90391b0.title: I understand the motivation to do so, but I’m not sure you can back up that it’s accurate to say…

paragraphs.text: I understand the motivation to do so, but I’m not sure you can back up that it’s accurate to say that the quality of most movies actually rests in the middle of the graph since that would mean most movies are just barely above watchable. Wouldn’t it be more likely that most movies are fine and mostly good entertainment and that it’s actually more…

b87695447622.title: The word “average” doesn’t mean that something is between the interval 3 and 7 in a distribution.

paragraphs.text: The word “average” doesn’t mean that something is between the interval 3 and 7 in a distribution. You arbitrarily defined it as such. And if you think that saying a movie near the bottom of the distribution of scores (which anything 5 and below would be) isn’t a barely watchable movie is maybe a misunderstanding of how most scores in movie review…
